Candidatus Caldatribacterium saccharofermentans is a proposed species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Caldatribacteriota (formerly known as Atribacteria). It is an anaerobic, thermophilic (heat-loving) bacterium that was discovered in a hot spring environment.

The key features of Candidatus Caldatribacterium saccharofermentans are:

1. Phylogeny: It is a member of the Caldatribacteriota phylum, which is a relatively recently described lineage of bacteria known to inhabit various anaerobic, high-temperature environments.

2. Morphology: The cells are described as small, rod-shaped, and non-spore-forming.

3. Metabolism: Candidatus Caldatribacterium saccharofermentans is an obligate anaerobe, meaning it can only grow in the absence of oxygen. It is capable of fermenting various carbohydrates, such as sugars, to produce organic acids as end products.

4. Habitat and Temperature: This bacterium was originally discovered in a hot spring, indicating it thrives in high-temperature, anoxic (oxygen-free) environments.

5. Genome and Genomic Features: Analysis of the partial genome sequence of Candidatus Caldatribacterium saccharofermentans has revealed insights into its metabolic capabilities and adaptations to the hot spring habitat.

It is important to note that Candidatus Caldatribacterium saccharofermentans is a proposed species, and its classification and characteristics may be subject to further investigation and refinement as more information becomes available through ongoing research.
